title: Hometown "Assassin" hits Delaware Theatre Company
text:
Hometown "Assassin" hits Delaware Theatre Company Ryan Cormier , The News Journal 9:39 a.m. EDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo Lewis (left, Garrett Lee Hendricks) and Frank (Ezra Knight) square off in "Playing the Assassin" at the Delaware Theatre Company. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNAL) Buy Photo 
It was 1991 when David Robson moved to Delaware, a few years before he seriously began focusing on playwriting. 
Since then, he’s attended plenty of shows at the Delaware Theatre Company in Wilmington and remembers a little dream popping into his head during one of his first visits: “Wow. Imagine if I was a playwright and had a play here? That would be so cool.” 
Sure, it would be cool except that the Delaware Theatre Company rarely hosts productions by Delawareans. 
As Bud Martin, executive director of the theater company, says, “I don’t know too many Delaware-based playwrights, but we’re a regional theater, so whenever we get to work with talent in the region, it helps suit the mission.” 
For Robson, 49, his dream is becoming a reality this week after nearly two decades writing short and full-length plays. 
His football-themed “Playing the Assassin” began previews Wednesday ahead of Saturday’s official opening night and will wrap up on Nov. 8. (Tickets are $30-$45 .) Buy Photo 
Frank (left, Ezra Knight) and Lewis (Garrett Lee Hendricks) square off in "Playing the Assassin" at the Delaware Theatre Company. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNAL) 
“Assassin” has already had several runs, starting in 2013 at the Act II Playhouse in Ambler, Pennsylvania, before moving to Penguin Rep Theatre in New York and TheaterWorks in Connecticut. 
The show makes its fourth stop in Robson’s adopted hometown, capitalizing on positive reviews, including one from The New York Times. 
When the show was at Penguin Rep last year, the Times wrote, “The story is not without its contrivances. But Mr. Robson’s compelling dialogue and forceful characters provide so much theatrical energy that once the play takes off, no one in the audience will quibble about its improbabilities.” Rihanna to mentor Delaware's Nadjah Nicole on 'The Voice' 
And, yes, the review is hanging on the wall at Robson’s home. After all, it took nearly 20 years of writing plays to get one. 
“That was a big day,” he says. “To me, it’s all about whether the play has a continued life and after the review, I knew it would just based on that.” 
It came at a good time. Even though he loved writing, a ton of success had not found him. Buy Photo 
David Robson is the playwright behind "Playing the Assassin" at the Delaware Theatre Company. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNAL) 
“There have been many times when I’m like, ‘Why am I still writing plays?’” he says during a chat ahead of a dress rehearsal earlier this week. “I enjoy it and I get a production once in a while, but it’s kind of like shouting in space and no one can hear you scream.” 
But he adds, “You have to be satisfied because there’s something you like about the process. If you’re doing it just to get notoriety or good reviews – and that’s always really nice – it’s not going to keep you going. There has to be that internal drive.” 
This is the show’s third run with the same two-man cast and director. Ezra Knight, who the Times wrote gave a “powerhouse performance,” is teamed up Garrett Lee Hendricks with Joe Brancato directing. Tracy Morgan coming back to Delaware after crash 
The 85-minute play is loosely based on a true story. 
In 1978, New England Patriots receiver Darryl Stingley reached for a preseason pass and was hit hard by Oakland Raiders safety Jack “The Assassin” Tatum – a hit that left Stingley paralyzed. 
“Assassin” is set 20 years later. Buy Photo 
Lewis (left, Garrett Lee Hendricks) and Frank (Ezra Knight) square off in "Playing the Assassin" at the Delaware Theatre Company. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNAL) 
The character of Frank (Knight) mirrors Tatum as a football player whose hit left a man in a wheelchair for the rest of his life. He meets with a television producer (Lewis) about the possibility of the former football players appearing together on air just before the Super Bowl. 
Robson first had the idea for the play after reading the headline of Tatum’s obituary in 2010. It read, “Jack Tatum dies at 61; Oakland Raider safety whose hit left Darryl Stingley paralyzed.” 
“He was more than that. Anyone is more than that one terrible thing they’ve done or didn’t mean to do – an event that they are defined by,” says Wilmington’s Robson, an associate professor teaching English and creative writing at Delaware County Community College in Media, Pennsylvania. “Sure he was a hard player, but that is what you’re supposed to do as a football player. 
“So when I read that and realized they had never had a reunion, I thought there’s the play. There’s unfinished business there.” Foxcatcher, du Pont subject of ESPN doc 
While the world of football hangs all around the play, “Assassin” focuses more on humanity, redemption and reconciliation and not the game that connected the pair for eternity. 
Even though “Assassin” is about more than football, it has come out at a time when hard hits, concussions and player safety are at the forefront in the National Football League. 
It’s undoubtedly a fortuitous twist of fate for Robson. And Martin happily adds, “For a producer looking to sell tickets, as well. I used to always say people make their luck, but in this case, it really was lucky.” IF YOU GO 
What: “Playing the Assassin,” written by Delaware playwright David Robson 
When: Runs through Nov. 8 
Where: Delaware Theatre Company, 200 Water St., Wilmington 
Information: delawaretheatre.org
